content: The "STELA Reauthorization Act of 2014" includes provisions related to communications and copyright. The Act extends authority, addresses retransmission consent negotiations, and repeals the integration ban. It also includes reports on various broadcasting and market areas. The "STELA Reauthorization Act of 2014" extends authority under the Communications Act of 1934 and addresses retransmission consent negotiations. No additional appropriations are authorized for this Act. The "STELA Reauthorization Act of 2014" extends authority under the Communications Act of 1934 and addresses retransmission consent negotiations, prohibiting television broadcast stations from coordinating negotiations with another station in the same local market without common control permitted by regulations. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to adjust margin and set a deadline for implementing regulations within 9 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 103. DELAYED APPLICATION OF JSA ATTRIBUTION RULE IN CASE OF WAIVER PETITION. SEC. 104. DELETION OR REPOSITIONING OF STATIONS DURING CERTAIN PERIODS. In the case of a party to a joint sales agreement in effect on the effective date of the amendment to Note 2(k)(2) of section 73.3555 of title 47, Code of Federal Regulations, who submits a waiver petition within 90 days after the enactment of this Act, they will not be in violation of ownership limitations until 18 months after the petition denial or December 31, 2016. SEC. 104. DELETION OR REPOSITIONING OF STATIONS DURING CERTAIN PERIODS. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to remove restrictions on moving local TV stations during audience measurement periods. SEC. 105. REPEAL OF INTEGRATION BAN. SEC. 105. REPEAL OF INTEGRATION BAN. The second sentence of section 76.1204(a)(1) of title 47, Code of Federal Regulations, will have no force or effect after the enactment of this Act. The Commission must remove this sentence from its rules within 180 days. The Comptroller General will conduct a study analyzing changes to carriage requirements for video distributors under the Communications Act of 1934 if statutory licensing requirements are phased out. The study will assess the impact on consumer prices and programming access. A report must be submitted within 18 months of the Act's enactment. After conducting a study on changes to carriage requirements for video distributors under the Communications Act of 1934, the Comptroller General will submit a report to congressional committees with recommendations for legislative or administrative actions. The report will also compare the results with a previous study conducted under the Satellite Television Extension and Localism Act of 2010. SEC. 107. LOCAL NETWORK CHANNEL BROADCAST REPORTS. On the 270th day after the enactment of this Act and annually thereafter, satellite carriers must submit a report to the Commission detailing the retransmission of local television broadcast signals in each market, including new and discontinued signals, as well as information on satellite capacity usage for local signal retransmission. The requirement for satellite carriers to submit reports on the retransmission of local television broadcast signals in each market will cease after 5 reports have been submitted. Definitions for "local market," "satellite carrier," and "television broadcast station" are provided in the Communications Act of 1934. SEC. 108. REPORT ON DESIGNATED MARKET AREAS. The Commission must submit a report within 18 months analyzing consumer access to broadcast programming from TV stations outside their local market and exploring alternatives to designated market areas. The Commission must analyze consumer access to broadcast programming from TV stations outside their local market and explore alternatives to designated market areas, as defined in section 122(j) of title 17, United States Code. This aims to provide consumers with more programming options and assess the potential impact on localism and broadcast television at local, regional, and national levels. SEC. 109. DEFINITIONS. In this title, "appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The term "Commission" refers to the Federal Communications Commission. SEC. 201 amends Chapter 1 of title 17, United States Code, by updating certain sections to reflect the year 2019 instead of 2014. SEC. 202 addresses the termination of a license. SEC. 202 terminates a license under Section 119 of title 17, United States Code, effective on December 31, 2019.
